Literature Review: Inflation-adjusted financial instruments have gained significant attention in recent years due to their ability to protect investors against the erosion of purchasing power caused by inflation. This literature review focuses on inflation-adjusted bonds, swaps, and derivatives, exploring their valuation methodologies, risk management strategies, and applications in monetary policy.Inflation-indexed bonds, also known as real return bonds or linkers, have been extensively studied in the financial literature. Shen and Corning (2001) provide a comprehensive overview of these instruments, highlighting their role in portfolio diversification and inflation protection. The authors emphasize that inflation-indexed bonds offer a unique opportunity for investors to hedge against unexpected inflation, a feature not available in conventional nominal bonds.The valuation of inflation-adjusted securities is typically based on the foreign currency extension of the Heath-Jarrow-Morton (HJM) term structure model. Jarrow and Yildirim (2003) present a pioneering work in this area, developing a model that treats real and nominal prices as two distinct 'currencies.' Their approach has become a cornerstone for subsequent research in the field, providing a robust framework for pricing inflation-linked derivatives.Building upon this foundation, Mercurio (2005) extends the HJM framework to incorporate both nominal and real forward rates, allowing for a more accurate representation of the term structure of interest rates in the presence of inflation. This model has proven particularly useful in the valuation of inflation swaps and other complex inflation-linked derivatives.Inflation swaps, which allow counterparties to exchange fixed payments for payments linked to an inflation index, have become increasingly popular in recent years. Hinnerich (2008) provides a detailed analysis of these instruments, discussing their structure, pricing mechanisms, and role in inflation risk management. The author emphasizes the importance of accurately modeling the term structure of both real and nominal interest rates for proper valuation of inflation swaps.In the realm of monetary policy, inflation-adjusted securities play a crucial role in estimating market expectations of future inflation. Gürkaynak et al. (2010) demonstrate how the yield spread between nominal and inflation-indexed bonds, known as the break-even inflation rate, can be used to extract both expected inflation and the inflation risk premium. This information is valuable for central banks in assessing the effectiveness of their monetary policies and gauging market sentiment regarding future inflation.However, Christensen et al. (2010) caution against the direct interpretation of break-even inflation rates as market expectations of future inflation. They argue that liquidity premiums and other market frictions can significantly distort these measures, necessitating more sophisticated models to decompose the various components of the break-even inflation rate.The development of inflation derivatives markets has further expanded the toolkit available for inflation risk management. Fleckenstein et al. (2014) examine the relationship between inflation-indexed bonds and inflation swaps, uncovering significant pricing anomalies between these closely related markets. Their findings suggest potential arbitrage opportunities and raise questions about the efficiency of inflation-linked markets.Despite the growing importance of inflation-adjusted securities, there is a notable gap in the literature comparing different valuation models for these instruments. Haubrich et al. (2012) make a valuable contribution in this direction by comparing several models for pricing inflation derivatives, including extensions of the Black-Scholes model and more sophisticated term structure models. However, their work also highlights the need for further research in this area, particularly in evaluating the performance of these models across different market conditions.The efficiency of inflation derivative markets remains an underexplored area in the literature. While studies such as Fleckenstein et al. (2014) have identified pricing anomalies, a comprehensive analysis of market efficiency, including factors such as liquidity, transaction costs, and information flow, is largely absent. This presents a promising avenue for future research, as understanding market efficiency is crucial for both practitioners and policymakers.In conclusion, the literature on inflation-adjusted bonds, swaps, and derivatives has made significant strides in developing valuation methodologies and understanding their role in monetary policy. The HJM framework and its extensions have proven particularly useful in modeling these instruments. However, there remains a need for further research, particularly in comparing different valuation models and assessing the efficiency of inflation derivative markets. As these instruments continue to play an important role in investment strategies and policy decisions, addressing these research gaps will be crucial for advancing our understanding of inflation-linked financial markets.
